text:
1 Plug your iPhone into a charger. When installing system updates, it's best to ensure that your iPhone will keep a full charge.

2 Connect to a wireless network. You'll want to be connected to a wireless network before installing any system updates, as they can be quite large and will eat through limited data plans quickly.

3 Open your iPhone's Settings. You can find the Settings app on one of your Home screens. It may be located in a folder labeled "Utilities."

4 Scroll down and tap General .

5 Tap Software Update .

6 Tap Download and Install if an update is available. If there is no update available, you'll see the "Your software is up to date" message. If your device is up to date, you have the most recent emoji updates available.

Older iOS devices will not get newer system, and therefore emoji, updates. For example, the iPhone 4S is no longer receiving system updates, and will not get emoji characters released after iOS 9.3.5. If there is no update available, you'll see the "Your software is up to date" message.

7 Wait for your update to download and install. This could take anywhere from 20 minutes to over an hour, depending on your connection speed and the size of the update. Your iPhone will reboot during the installation process and the Apple logo will display as it is being installed. This could take anywhere from 20 minutes to over an hour, depending on your connection speed and the size of the update.

8 Open an app that uses your keyboard. Once the update has been installed, you can check for your new emoji characters by opening your keyboard.

9 Tap the emoji button. You'll see this when the keyboard is open on your screen, to the left of the space bar. It looks like a smiley face. If you have multiple keyboards installed, you may need to press and hold the Globe button to select "Emoji."

If you're not seeing the emoji keyboard, you may need to enable it. Tap Settings → General → Keyboard → Keyboards → Add New Keyboard → Emoji. You'll see this when the keyboard is open on your screen, to the left of the space bar. It looks like a smiley face.
